International Tributes to the History of Flight
First East-to-West Atlantic Crossing
On April 12, 1928, Hermann Kohl and his two-man
crew set out on a mission that many believed was
After a 37-hour flight, the "Bremen" set down safely
at 12:35 p.m. on April 13.
impossible. Aboard the Junkers W-33 "Bremen," a
single-engine, all-metal aircraft, the trio planned to
The full-color cachet depicts the "Bremen" in flight
fly the Atlantic from east to west. At 5:38 a.m., they over the Atlantic. The map above the plane traces the
took off from Baldonnel Field near Dublin, Ireland.
route of the crossing, from Ireland to the northeast
coast of Newfoundland and finally to Greenly Island.
Many attempts had been made to fight the treach-

erous air currents hindering an East-to-West Cross-by Germany in 1979. It pictures the Junkers W-33
ing. The Bremen was the first aircraft to succeed,

properties.sfomuseum:description: Airmail flight cover, part of International Tributes to the History of Flight series by the Postal Commemorative Society; white envelope with full color illustration cachet and inset stamp commemorating first/inaugural east-to-west Atlantic crossing on April 12, 1928, in Dublin, Ireland, by Hermann Koehl with Junkers W-33 “Bremen” airplane; stamp dated April 12, 1984 in Baile Atha Cliath; includes information on reverse.
